text: this is CJ Chivers reporting for the New
York Times Russia's military invasion of
Georgia continued on Monday with what
appeared to be the opening of a second
front out of Abkhazia the other enclaves
the fighting had started on Friday when
Russia moved columns of armor and
artillery and its infantry into South
Ossetia smaller enclave in the mountains
Hassan clave is much larger and mostly
coastal everybody involved in this fight
right now is trying to determine what
Russia's intentions are the initial hope
as it became clear that they were going
to invade was that they would stop with
the annexation of the two ethnic
enclaves which have been disputed
territory since the collapse of the
Soviet Union
it appears that they have gone well past
those enclaves what is not clear is what
their objectives are diplomats and
analysts who are watching the fight say
that they may be seeking to destroy the
georgian military forces to disable them
indefinitely and weaken the Georgian
government George itself says that
Russia's attentions are far broader and
that they seek to overthrow the
government of President Mikhail
Saakashvili this would be a clear
demonstration of Russia's strength in
the region and in some ways a
retaliation for mr. Saakashvili's
policies which have annoyed the Kremlin
since he came to power in 2004 there's
some fear as well that Russia may go
beyond that what one Georgian official
told me would be the maximum solution
occupation of the entire country of
Georgia with its seaports and the oil
pipeline there have been signed as well
coming from the Kremlin that they have
some lesser included goals one of the
more curious announcements of sunday was
that the kremlin was deploying criminal
investigators to South Ossetia to begin
the forensic collection of what it
called evidence of war crimes
that would suggest that there may be an
objective here of branding mr.
Saakashvili a war criminal for public
relations purposes and perhaps even in
the future seeking some sort of public
procedure against him it's interesting
to note that in the past conflicts which
began in the early 1990s in both South
Ossetia and Abkhazia that there have
been allegations on both sides of war
crimes
